review_title: Great place, depending on where you work in the organization
pros:
Has a good benefits package. Tuition Waiver is great benefit if you are able to use it. Depending on your position, you may or may not be allowed to take classes during the day. There are graduate level programs that have classes in the evenings though. My favorite thing about CWRU is the people. For the most part, everyone has been great to work with.

 Located in University Circle which has lots of museums and restaurants.
cons:
The culture in some areas is not ideal. So, depending on where you work you might love it or hate it. CWRU is trying to fix this issue with Pathway 4 of the new strategic plan. Compensation is not the best but the university is assessing it's compensation scheme now. 

There's no clear career path for any position.

review_title: No one is in academia to get rich.
pros: There is a perpetual learning curve that either feeds self-edification or builds skills to take elsewhere. The area is an education / culture goldmine. Take from it what you will. I was able to more or less make my own hours. As long as data came in and looked good, I was free to manage my schedule as I liked.
cons: It's a very comfortable place which means people have to look for things to complain about and they do.  Your experience is 100% luck of the draw based on how your personality fits with others and scientists are not exactly known for their social skills. The office politics are as bad as they are anywhere, despite low-risk work and easy-going environment. Everyone should be enamored with the wonder of learning but that's not the culture.  Faculty stress is enormous and it trickles down. Promotions are arbitrary based on grant money available and how lackadaisical your supervisor is or isn't and how much he/she likes you. 13 years of networking with other techs shows me that this is universal.  The University itself does not care about you unless you bring them money or prestige. Everyone else might as well be floor sweepers.

review_title: Don't! No, seriously, just don't work at CWRU.
pros:
Tuition waiver can make it almost worth working here.

Some positions have a direct enough impact that they might provide a sense of fulfillment and service. Most positions are just cogs in the machinery though.

Generally pro-LGBTQ policies.
cons:
Compensation tends to run around 50-75% market rate. Raises are usually 1-2.5% per year, 3-4% if you're really lucky and your manager is willing to go out on a limb for you. 

Benefits used to be good (one of the traditional perks of working in academia) but have rapidly retracted over the past 5-8 years. In addition to rising premiums, co-insurance and deductibles have been added to the plans, greatly increasing out-of-pocket expenses.

There is a pattern of emotionally abusive, bullying, harassing, and/or inept 
individuals in middle-to-upper managerial roles. Complaints to HR rarely result in visible action against managers. Repeat offenders often retain direct supervisory roles.

The Board of Trustees are pushing the university to operate more like a corporation than an institute of higher learning.

Poor financial decisions by her predecessor have forced President Snyder to function primarily as a fundraising machine to prepare for rapidly approaching balloon payments on nine-figure loans.

Incoming undergraduate class sizes have roughly doubled in the past decade during a period of financial austerity, which has led to growing pains in terms of physical space, staffing, funding, and more.

Leadership is white- and male-heavy.

review_title: Not the best place for a young person - unless you need education benefits.
pros: Benefits are better than average. Great free training (Photoshop, video editing, languages, etc.) offered. Interesting events on campus and around, great location. The University is well respected in the region. There are a lot of good networking opportunities and some exceptional people working within the University and in the organizations in the area. Education benefits for full-time employees means you could get a free part-time education. Work hours can be very flexible (depending on your manager).
cons: Staff salaries are lower than average. There is very little attention paid to personal and career development; age and rank trumps competence; a perfect fit with a job description (regardless of whether it is outdated or inaccurate) trumps identifying talent and developing it. As with any large organization, and especially in a tight regional economy, there are a lot of politics, particularly around money and (perceived) internal competition. Ignoring or being on the wrong side of the game could be to the detriment of your career. Decision-making is very top-down, bureaucracy can seriously slow down projects. Top management's communication is opaque while trying to feign transparency.

review_title: Great place to work - if you work in the great department it is.
pros: I've made great friends over the years - most of co-workers are pleasure to deal with. Students are bright and refreshing.  Most of the faculty know what they are doing and what their role is.  Some can be difficult to work with.
cons: Depending on the department and school,  the management can be horrible at one and great at another. HR is a joke (employee is not their friend, remember);  Health insurance is expensive ($400/mo for 3 people) ; parking cost is outrageous ($107/mo!);  gym on site $60/mo; zero opportunity to grow;  salary for MS in Engineering was $35k to start and $46k after 10 years working there (the lowest of the low!); commute to and from work was very long...

pros: The biggest reason to work at CWRU is the free tuition benefit. You can get your advanced degree for free! Other benefits (other than salary) are also fantastic including a pension, over 3 weeks of time off (increasing to more than 4 after working there for 5 years), and great health plans.
cons: The base salary is not competitive at all. Working down the street at the Cleveland Clinic can automatically boost you probably over 15% in the same type of position. There also isn't much room to grow unless you are a PhD or an MD.

review_title: Great place to work, but vertical movement is difficult.
pros: Tuition is covered for employees (+family), positive work environment that is greatly enriched by the students and proximity to University Circle, good job security, vacation does not include university holidays (and there are many!), IT Services/Software at CWRU are second to none - my office rarely had any IT issues and when we did they were immediately fixed.
cons: Promotions and pay increases are difficult to come by. There is very little turnover in the middle and upper management, so there are not many opportunities to advance your career within the university structure... oh, and the parking situation is remarkably bad.

pros: The campus is good, despite being located near parts of Cleveland with high crime rate. There are some good efforts made by the university to support researchers.  Excellent computing facilities are typically available.
cons: Collegial experience when collaborating on research projects is a mixed bag; some interactions reflect values of students from mid to high level institutions while other interactions indicate ethics and values from mid to low level institutions. Parking, perhaps not surprisingly, is expensive. Postdoctoral salary and benefits are not commensurate with skills and experience, though this is a problem not specific to CWRU.

pros: Cleveland is a cheap city to live in. Postdocs are just starting to get recognized within the university
cons: Benefits/healthcare are not great especially if you have a family that also needs healthcare. Grad students may have better healthcare than postdocs. Management doesn't know whether to lump us with students or staff, because we are neither. A lot of emphasis of course is given towards grad students and undergrads, but for this university to consider itself a university that can train future researchers or professors, not a lot of support is given towards professional or career development of postdocs, who train current grad students, drive research in the university, and bring in grants. Work/life balance depends on your adviser, like in any university, but there are no checks/balances as to if your boss has been abusing you or not.

pros: Generally Excellent on the benefits and work life balance side,. Options for learning can be huge dependent on your specific supervisor. One of the few companies I know that still has a pension.
cons: Poor at the management and communications side. Divide between faculty and staff as second class employees is pretty huge. Respect can be good dependent on your particular contact with specific faculty, or it can be poor

pros: the university had good name recognition and there were some exciting projects on the books which made it very attractive to excellent students
cons: the management was completely out of touch with the needs of the academic community. the lack of stability was epidemic, the sky was falling at every meeting with no solution other than hope for better days, very passive and ineffective. eventually this cash crunch led to salary caps, nullifying negotiated start-up funds for long-term laboratory operations and massive flight of employees to safer institutions or industry. we academics tried to right the boat with non binding non-confidence votes, good management would have engaged the complaints, this one lashed out visciously and haphazardly.  I have worked in over 4 academic institutions and this was hands down the absolute worst

pros:
Work-life balance

review_title: Love my students, colleagues (all but the upper administration)
pros: The students are enthusiastic about taking on challenging scientific problems, and are mostly well prepared.  My colleagues are great collaborators and scientists.  The quality of interdisciplinary work (despite administrative obstacles) keeps me going.  Good place to do science.
cons: We pay our graduate students, postdocs, and faculty at all levels a pittance compared to universities with similar (or weaker) scholarship.  Great place to land if you are a two-career (two-income) couple.  If you are the sole breadwinner, look elsewhere.  Maybe our alumni just haven't had enough success in their careers the last 80 years.

HR department is very easy to work with and provides great customer service. Generous policies. Nice perks in terms of gym access and a beautiful, safe environment.
cons: Many people are either coasting or actively looking for the next thing. Many people seem bored and/or stifled. Cleveland has a difficult market for career development, so it’s not really Case’s fault. The pay is laughably low until you consider that the responsibilities and expectations tend also be low for many positions.

review_title: It all depends on where you work!
job_title: Department Assistant III in Cleveland, OH
pros: I would say the best part of working here is the name recognition, free schooling for employees, discounts, diversity, and its philanthropy initiatives. Also, the current CEO (Barbara Snyder) has worked hard in transforming the university into a much more positive working environment.
cons: Each department works as if its a separate entity with its own budget to operate as they see fit. Even as far as required dress code. There are so many departments and this sometimes causes animosity among employees that perceive other departments as receiving special treatment. Favoritism in promotions instead of best qualified.

pros: Extensive health,  insurance coverage, easy work hours.  You can't get fired... they are so gunshy of being sued - classic academia.  People work there for years "pulling paychecks" for doing as little work they can get away with.
cons: Minimal opportunities for advancement, annual salary % increase cap has been 3% for the last 5 years.  Doesn't offset the 10% increase in health insurance cost per employee.   Most departments are understaffed for the responsibilities but is is a non-profit and academia..  There is minimal accountability for work responsibilities so its okay if you don't work at full potential - which is impossible without proper staffing - in the long run no one notices...

review_title: If you're Admin Staff, Benefits and Compensation not Competitive.
pros: It's a nice area to work in during the day. We have a great President in Barbara. However, could use younger, bright and forward-thinking minds around her.
cons: High turnover as Staff (non-faculty) get the short end of the stick. Case is one of the, if not the lowest paying College/University for Staff in Northeast Ohio. Poor tuition reimbursement policies (only about 2k per year which is roughly 3/4 of 1 class). On the employment side, Case does not seem to embrace young talent. Lots of older people with old-school ideas making decisions when we're trying to be cutting edge and Progressive.

pros: Close to the city where I grew up.  Decent work-life balance.  The time off policies are good on paper but there is little oversight so you rarely can use them.
cons: Granting levels to faculty are low so salaries start low and remain there.  Yearly increases are generally capped at 2% as a matter of policy and the average merit-based increase is 1% so do not expect to improve upon your starting wage without being promoted.

job_title: Research Assistant IV in Cleveland, OH
pros:
Flexible environment
Some efforts to support employee health and well-being
cons:
A lot of the environment depends on where you're working and your particular supervisor
University is very siloed from college to college, department to department
Childcare benefits are non-existent, not many nearby options
Transportation options (biking, transit to work) could be better supported, but strides are being
Dichotomy of staff benefits versus benefits to faculty (ex faculty get 14 weeks of paid maternity leave, staff get 6)
Career support and opportunity for advancement depends entirely on department/supervisor
Very cumbersome travel and reimbursement policies that nearly require employees to front costs
Low salary

review_title: Reviewing CWRU, but was Employee of MetroHealth Medical Center (Associated with CWRU)
pros: Strong academic environment.  Affiliated with two large and very diverse health systems and two excellent medical schools (CWRU, CCF)
cons: Our institution was on the other side of town from the CWRU "Hub".  There was a palpable disconnect between the two institutions, which is telling more about the relationship between MetroHealth and CWRU than perhaps CWRU itself.

review_title: Case - remember you are there for the students.
pros: The benefit package is above average, my department was fairly flexible in scheduling working hours at short notice.  Great atmosphere as long as you work well with people from different cultures.  Most students take their education seriously, and know what they are there for.  Good mix of afterwork activities and campus projects to keep you busy.
cons: At busy times (begining and end of semesters), people tend to be very short with each other.  Students are dfficult to deal with during these times.  Realize that with out them, you would not have a job there.

pros: education opportunities, each department has different approach to management so if you're lucky you can land in a great department
cons: no room for growth, salary is not merit-based (you can do the twice the amount of work as a peer colleague and get same salary raise), culture is very siloed and staff are not listened to. HR doesn't work for staff, but for financial interests of the university, little to no change happens in management culture, lots of wasted work to meet the political wims of random leadership

pros: Bright, talented students, world-class research, significant opportunity to contribute to the education of students through my department/role.
cons: Staff are not particularly well-valued at the institution. Compensation is average for the field. Benefits are ok, but again, those for faculty are better. Lots of silos, lots of people who think everything on campus revolves around them. Not as much collaboration (by faculty with staff in particular) as there could or should be.

pros: Large organization with varied jobs.  Beautiful Campus. Interesting environment.
cons: Managers might be technically competent but lack in their management skills.  HR is useless in terms of employee advocacy.  It's not clear to me what HR does other than administer benefits and compensation.  Issues become bigger than they need to be. There is no where to go for direction.  Management Center HR units can not (or do not) handle the volume but act in some ways as gatekeepers.   If you are not in the "inner circle" you have a hard time being seen or getting heard.

review_title: As a research associate, I was pretty satisfied in CWRU
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Cleveland, OH
pros: People are open-minded in the campus. There is cultural variety as well. the senior management is well done. The benefits are reasonably good. Nice environment. Cleveland is much better than most people think. Especially families with kids have a lot things to explore. many museums, playground. It is safe to live around Cleveland heights too. Nice area.  plenty of choice of restaurants
cons: there is no research professor position in CWRU. Many good scientists decide to leave after years being research associates. This way they can't keep the good people. I wish they could change this quickly.

review_title: A great place to work if you don't need the money
job_title: Business Analyst II in Cleveland, OH
pros: A great place to work with some of the brightest minds in the city. Great benefits. Good flexibility and autonomy, with generally enlightened views on training employees. Together with hiring policies this tends to lead to competent employees which are good to work with.
cons: Pay is limited compared to private sector, and there are hard caps on merit raises. Some departments experience infighting (but not most).

pros: Case has really bright undergraduates, and the caliber of graduate students is generally high -- especially in social work and nursing. Deans grasp the basics of how to encourage new faculty in developing their research.
cons: Tenure and promotion standards are really high, and the process is not transparent. Despite efforts to improve, Case is still a tough place for women faculty. Some department chairs run their own fiefdoms.

pros: Lots of opportunities to learn--great environment, especially for medicine. Having UH and the Clinic next door is unique.
cons: Compensation is not attractive---at least in the research assistant position. It's hard to gain any respect as a research assistant --and there is not much room from growth. It feels like they just want research assistants to do all the grunt work (that computers and high school students should be doing- but they want you to have a Master's Degree to do it, and then pay you $30k). Parking is far from whenever you want to be and expensive (~$100/mo).

pros: I was a faculty at Case for a few years. I enjoyed the flexible work environment . The research environment was collaborative and collegial in my early years. School also provides with great benefits.
cons: Quality of Students on Decline in the business school. Intellectual environment not as stimulating as it used to be. I saw steep decline in the quality of research output at the business school. School became more of a teaching school in last couple of years.

review_title: Was once a good place to work in IT
pros: Generous 403b plan, casual dress and working on a college campus.  Working on a college campus is exciting and always great to see new students thrive in a challenging environment.  Generally a laid back atmosphere with what I believe to be on the lower end of the stress level.
cons: In IT, the model is going outsourced as a everything as a service.  In other words, if you are not Faculty, Student or a Researcher, they really don't want the overhead of a FTE.

review_title: Good place to attend graduate school if you're not too concerned with student life.
pros: As a humanities grad student, Case lacks in prestige vs. it's science programs, but it does offer good teaching experience and plenty of opportunities for professional development.
cons: Not a lot of social opportunities, Case has a very nerdy vibe, which is good if you're particularly studious, but a bummer if you're coming from an undergrad program with a larger party scene.

job_title: Department Assistant III in Cleveland, OH
pros:
Great Benefits
Fantastic people to work with
Learning & Growing environment conducive to your own personal & professional growth
No glass ceiling and always room for advancement
Pres. Barbara Snyder is a force to be reckoned with. She gets it done and is just a great person.
Employees and their children enjoy educational benefits.
cons:
Proprietary financial & human capital system might drive you nuts (but we're all in it together so you have plenty to commiserate with)
Parking is very expensive and often far

job_title: Senior Staff/Executive Administration in Cleveland, OH
pros: The culture at CWRU is professional and friendly.  The campus is beautiful and well maintained.  The campus community stays well connected through activities and daily newsletters.  University President Barbara Snyder, faculty, and staff have really done amazing things the past few years.
cons: If you live outside of the campus area the drive to and from work tends to be tedious (lots of traffic lights and in winter traffic jams happen frequently).  The university makes an effort to mitigate the traffic issues by posting traffic advisories and allowing for early release on bad weather days.

review_title: Great job for those with a family or going back to school, bad if you like money or career advancement
pros: If you want to go back to school (college or graduate school), working for CWRU is great since they will pay for 2 classes per semester (1 class in the summer) for full time employees.  If you have children or a spouse that want to go to college, CWRU wil also pay for their classes.  In order to take classes and receive a degree, you must apply and be accepted into the program.  Since Case is the highest ranking university in Ohio, going to school for free is a great benefit.  Another great benefit of working at Case is the informal atmosphere (at least in research) and the vacation (3 wks), health and other employee benefits.  Also, if you enjoy the symphony and museums, the Cleveland Orchestra is on the same campus at Case, as well as many of the major museums in Cleveland.
cons: One major downside is the low pay compared to similar jobs in the corporate sector or even compared to other colleges.  Another disadvantage is that you can not advance within Case without having a Ph.D.  So, career advancement is poor.  Third, there is a lot of trivial research being done at universities, and Case is no exception.  So, if you are in pursuit of higher level scientific research, this may not be the best place to work.  Finally, the environment around the campus is very "urban".  Cleveland itself is a very poor city, with high unemployment and poverty rates.  Consequently, there is a lot of crime around campus, and sometimes on campus, which leads to a very unsafe feeling, especially when you see people wandering around the campus and you know that they aren't students.  Furthermore, besides the museum and orchestra, there is not much around the campus to go to or do.  Another downside is that you have to pay for parking and there is no easy way to commute to Case (too many stop lights).

review_title: The cost of living is increasing but the pay and opportunities aren't
job_title: Department Assistant III/Chair Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros:
Flexibility, work and personal life balance is great, the opportunity to participate in workshops, PD's etc..., tuition reimbursement/tuition exchange is great, other benefits are good such as discount car rental, amusement tickets etc...

Disclaimer:  I would recommend the university to others but providing them all of the information I've provided here for them to make the best decision.

The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because of the issues listed.
cons:
The pay is very low, the raises is set at 2% and the 2% isn't even given.  There aren't any bonuses.  All of the pay goes to the President, deans, faculty pretty much all top level.  In five years my pay has increased $1,091.  You're thinking, why did I take the job, well at the time I thought I'd be able to increase my salary via raises, bonus etc...or even move upward to another position but that turned out not to be the case.

The organization touts pay internal pay equity as a reason not to pay a fair wage.  Just because someone has the same title, doesn't mean that everyone has the same amount of experience or education etc....so clearly everyone's pay shouldn't be the same.

Moving within the organization isn't a guarantee of a higher salary either--someone may fair better coming from outside but once in you're stuck to 2% increases if that so negotiate well.  Moving within the organization also isn't a given either because those hiring usually have a person in mind already so going through the interview process is just that a process.

Also, the culture from department to department throughout the university is very different so where I may enjoy the flexibility and the option to complete workshops etc...others may not have that luxury with their manager/supervisor.


The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because of the issues listed.

pros: Area around CWRU is being developed adding amenities. Use of facilities on campus (gym, etc) is nice.  Fundraising is active through current president. Pension and financial benefits are nice.
cons: Meidcal School does not invest in modern technologies (e.g. Core facilities, computing, infrastructure) and is years behind most institutions. Very little internal support, or subsidization of any kind, for large scale projects. Administrative decision making seems to be centralized through individuals who are out of touch. Health benefits are bad and going downhill each year. Pay for parking. Motivated by financial gain than any true science.

review_title: Work Environment is Hit and Miss
pros:
Great academic, health, and wellness benefits - especially for family at college age. 
Good food designed by culinary students at BRB Cafe. 
Monthly parking and discounted RTA passes.
cons:
HR is mostly disorganized or gives incomplete or incorrect information. 
Parking and RTA passes are discounted, but expensive given low salaries in academia. 
The University has unenforceable policies, a nice gesture but ultimately not as helpful as it seems.

pros: Case Western Reserve University has many opportunities for students to get employed while on campus. These jobs often offer flexible hours, a very dynamic work environment, and a lot of room for creativity and self expression.
cons: I can't think of many bad things in terms of working for Case Western Reserve University. On downside may be the inconsistency between wages for similar jobs. For example, I've been a teaching assistant for two classes and have gotten paid different hourly wages for each class.

review_title: Not a good place to be administrative staff
job_title: Department Assistant I in Cleveland, OH
pros: The location is really nice and the campus is beautiful in the spring/summer.  The benefits are pretty good and you have access to a variety of options.
cons: Staff salaries are poor unless you are on the executive level.  Parking is ridiculously expensive.  The culture of the workplace is similar to a caste system.

review_title: Grad Student Life in School of Engineering
pros:
1) Excellent opportunities for collaboration with hospitals and healthcare organizations in Cleveland. 
2) Relatively good work-life balance in most research groups.
3) Some novel, groudbreaking research occurring in select labs.
cons:
1) Until recently, leadership has been lacking within departments and school of engineering.
2) School is slow to replace faculty, leaving some research/teaching tracks poorly staffed.
3) Lack of oversight within some departments can leave students stranded in failing programs for years, and there is little professional development within the department.

pros: Case has a really friendly staff. Good team atmosphere. There exists plenty of room for growth in different directions within the university.
cons: They have too many different reporting programs, but this is expected with such a large university. Communication between the departments could be better, but at least everyone has a similar goal, so it is not too bad.

review_title: Case is great place to work.
pros: Very flexible with employee benefits - time off, sick leave, family leave.  Provide good training benefits.  University system has strong communications within the university community and very strong up-to-date policies.
cons: Salary levels for staff employees significantly below similar responsibility levels in the corporate world.  Faculty management sometimes prevents good management practices that would benefit the entire university.  Central administration does a yeoman's job at trying to establish good policy which often is ignored or dismissed by faculty.

review_title: As a researcher in physics I had access to great facilities, friendly HR, and world-class faculty.
pros: If you are looking for work in a world-class research environment this is the place for you. While most of the work is allocated to graduate students and senior faculty, if you are qualified in the pure science, medical, or engineering field, this is a place to look for technical openings.
cons: The overall management of the University can at times be questionable. The PR and transparency of the University's management and administration as well as free-speech leaves room for the imagination.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cleveland, OH
pros: Professional staff and scientists with whom I collaborate. Top of the line research facilities; its obvious Case has a fairly large budget when it comes to bio-medical research.
cons: The location; Cleveland is bitter cold in the winter.

review_title: The experience was overall positive and the last few years definitely showed improvement in working conditions
pros: Good for biomedical research, beautiful campus, nice library facility, good faculty, opportunities for growth, collaborations with the Cleveland Clinic foundation
cons: Small departments, not enough diversity, less number of faculty, reduced funding opportunities for students, teaching assistants are not recruited and treated properly, cold weather of Cleveland

job_title: Student Project Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: Office culture was extremely kind and accepting. Employees were flexible with students and understood that school work is a big part of student's lives. Students were treated with respect and could easily develop into leaders in the work place
cons: There was a clear lack of training for student employees. Often times we were left unsupervised to figure out how to use software on our own which severely slowed the learning process.

review_title: If you're not a professor, don't even think about it.
pros: Fantastic location situated among the museums and park. Great lunch spots. Some really nice activities available nearby. Also, great benefit getting free classes.
cons: Like working with pigs fighting to get at the trough. If you aren't trying to take advantage of the situation, you might as well be an alien. No longer offering MBA classes to employees.

pros: Flexible scheduling, tuition benefit IF you can use it, smart and creative colleagues, opportunities to do interesting work if you're lucky
cons: Sub-par HR policy and procedure, staff has no "voice", pay scale typically 15 - 20% below market rate unless you're an exec, tiny tiny pay increases (basically, if you're here for more than 2 years, you're losing money)

pros: Great Staff, A lot of Equipment. Has a pool, basketball courts, rock climbing wall, squash and racquetball courts, and on the staff trainers to help you.
cons: Some of the Equipment they have has some age on it. Would recommend bringing your own basketball and any other equipment you need.

review_title: Good place to work, laid-back atmosphere
pros: Somewhat laid back atmosphere, good coffee, colleagues are pleasant and easy to work with, interesting institution to be associated with, nice campus.
cons: Workload can be sporadic, sometimes there isn't much to do, other times there is too much to be done, not much guidance from management on completing projects sometimes.

pros: Good Research Atmosphere. People and colleagues are very friendly. The campus is not big, anything to do is very convennient.
cons: Cleveland is close to Erie lake. So, in the winter, we often have heavy snow here. If you are living a little far away from the campus, you may have some suffering time in winter.

review_title: Research environment is great, administration not so good
pros: Case is small enough that you will end up slowly meeting everybody in your field. Research environment is good, nice faculty. If one seeks collaboration with UH, that is pretty nice.
cons: Salaries are controlled excessively even where there is money to give. They prefer to send money back than to give it to the people that deserve it. Administration is moving slowly.

review_title: A business model of doing Science.
pros: Easy access to state-of-art instruments, enough financial support for purchasing convenient reagents, have the chance to talk to a wide variety of famous professors from other universities, easily to find someone who has published on Nature, Science, Cell etc. journals to share some experience and the story behind the work with you.
cons: Not a place for doing perfect science, have to keep moving forward, thus have to comprise achieving perfection.

pros: Many intelligent, accomplished, and capable faculty who care about making a meaningful and lasting difference in the world. Secretaries are the glue of the departments.
cons: Student affairs does very little (or next to nothing) to mediate conflict between graduate students and faculty. Make sure you have a good advisor to help protect you. No ombudsmen.

pros:
Great place to work. Benefits are good.  People are very friendly and will to help others.
I would recommend this employer to everyone.
cons:
I have no cons for this employer - this is a great place to work.  Benefits are good.  People are very friendly and will to help others.
I would recommend this employer to everyone.

review_title: Your compensation will represent 80% of your marketable value.
pros: The tuition benefit is fantastic. Great location.The people who make up the community are generally very worth knowing. CWRU is extremely competent at supplying schwag items at events promoting initiatives which they will later discontinue.
cons: No standards for ensuring competency among those with supervisory responsibility. It is virtually guaranteed that your department will be reorganized or outsourced within five years of your hire date. Sub-standard compensation. The HR machine will crush your enthusiasm if you speak up.

pros: You can advance your education with free tuition.  Fall/Spring semester, you can take up to six course hour classes.  It takes a while to complete degrees, but it worth doing it.
cons: Management is up to PI in the lab.  If you are lucky, you can get flexible work hour and take classes.

job_title: Research Assistant in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Amazing oppurtunity for growth and friendly work enviorment! It is a tight knit community almost family like which has its own pros and cons
cons: The only real downside of working at case western reserve university is the pay compensation for research is on low end of area median salaries

review_title: Weigh your options!  CWRU is a dead end career
job_title: Alumni Center Coordinator in Cleveland, OH
pros: Get to leave work at 5pm
cons:
Bureaucracy of lowly skilled and overweight women that micromanage your every move
The "work" you are doing isn't dynamic or fulfilling
The Alumni Association is by far the worst branch to be stuck at
The culture is as bad as it gets
No accountability by "Upper Management"
It's hilarious everyone has an "Assistant Director" of something title
In my job I was literally graded on how to properly fold a linen
Every job at CWRU is a dead-end job
No opportunities for professional growth
The HR department literally are paper pushers, don't expect them for help on anything

review_title: Case Western Reserve University is a faded glory.
pros: Good benefits overall, although they are curtailed every year.
cons: There are too many pretentious administrators with six-figure salaries and too many incompetent staff members. The real workforce at the helm, i.e. the faculty members, are stressed out and frustrated. Most of them are very pessimistic about the future of Case and of Academia in general.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cleveland, OH
pros: The campus has a very good research and learning atmosphere. The environment is cozy and delightful. People here are friendly. Very good place to work
cons: I don't see any cons. I don't see any cons. I don't see any cons. I don't see any cons. I don't see any cons. I don't see any cons.

review_title: Wonderful place to get started or grow
job_title: Director of Development in Cleveland, OH
pros: There are few places in Cleveland that carry the prestige of CWRU in Development. The staff is undoubtedly competent and lead the industry in strategy and execution. The pay is more than adequate and the opportunity for growth is expansive.
cons: The benefits are middle-of-the-pack.  Logistics change quickly and often (office space, etc.).

review_title: This was a great place to work, I learned a great deal during my time there.
pros: Family friendly policies, intellectual stimulation, great people, woman led organization, great reputation
cons: Like many large organizations things often moved slow.  The culture of higher education is collaboration while this was great for buy in it often slowed down the process.

pros: Good work experience, and a great way to earn letters of recommendation. I worked with my PI and several grad students around 8 hours a week.
cons: Work experience can be highly variable depending on who you actually end up working with. Many students complain about absentee PI's where they have little time to discuss work.

pros: I worked at a lab assistant at CWRU during my undergraduate career. I had experiences with a few different PIs were some very good and some weren't. There is no shortage of good instructors who can help set you on your right career path.
cons: While there are a lot of opportunities for research, you can have some PIs or grad students who can barely speak English. This can make communication and progression of projects very difficult.

review_title: Great place to work, great people, good hours, low pay
pros: Great hours, wonderful benefits, you get to work with some of the brightest there is, loved working with dental students, and residents.  Great opportunity to learn, great opportunities to attend the college. Paid sick, paid vacation, paid holidays.
cons: Low pay, most of the time under staffed, overbearing supervisor (at least in my department), low raises, no holiday bonuses.

review_title: Great place to work but low pay
pros: Excellent University setting with lots of intelligent people to work with in the research community.   Beautiful settings with lots of museums, green space, restaurants , Severence orchestra .easy access to downtown Cleveland.  Good benefits.
cons: Low pay,  not much room for advancement.

review_title: Too much work, unreasonable expectations and deadlines, management is authoritarian.
pros: If you can take advantage of it, tuition is waived for employees. There are tuition concessions for family members too.
cons: There is too much work to get done with unreasonable expectations and deadlines. Management views their employees as entities that they own, to be instructed, and to squeeze as much work out of them as possible. Parking is expensive and far from the office.

review_title: Valuable student employment that helped me achieve my academic and professional goals
pros: Flexible work hours, decent pay (for the type of work involved), access to a variety of legal work and the opportunity to get to know professors practicing in a variety of areas.
cons: After leaving the position you will continuously see your former supervisors, can  be a pro if the relationship was positive.  The work experience isn't quite a valuable at a summer/internship at a law firm

pros: The benefits here can't be beat, really, but you pay for that with lower pay, so it really depends on what is important to you.  When there are openings, it is easy to move around to different positions, and therefore easy to make this you employer for life.
cons: Pay is on the lower end.  Many jobs are grant and contract funding dependent. Parking is expensive and most lots not close.

pros: you can learn a lot of academic knowledge from Professors. the work environment is very comfortable and people are nice to each other.
cons: the work is very routine and detailed orinted. there is no much chanllenge. the promotion opportunity is much less than other organizations.

pros: Great organization with a lot of hard working individuals.  The best perk is the discount for taking class on top of your job responsibilities if pursuing an advanced degree.
cons: Your level of success seems to depend on the department you work in.  It can be frustrating if you find yourself in an office/environment with a lot of complacent individuals, but this does not seem to be the norm

review_title: Excellent range of experiences for PhD students.
pros:
Case Western provides an excellent space where collaboration is highly encouraged for PhD students.

Lots of seminars and chances to interact and learn more about a variety of fields.
cons: The lack of payment for PhD students who are TAing can be frustrating especially since 3 are required for graduation.

pros: Nice people. Flexible working hours.
cons: Pay is ultra low, easily 40% below market for most. Ancient processes and turtle like time frames for any simple task. Hiring a person can take over 3 months. It doesn't matter if the position is for a department administrator or a VP. Processes at the University are slow, paper driven and dated. Everything from HR to Purchasing to Legal, everything moves at a snails pace and is something out of the 1950's. Pay is incredibly low in contrast to even local community colleges. Raises are a laughable two percent at there highest level for most employees, which means with inflation you are actually losing money each year. College promotes not on accomplishment, ability or performance, but on how many years one has been with the institution. The first thing a Case employee tells you when meeting them is how many years they have been with the institution. There are many people at Case who haven't had a new idea in 30 years and they're proud of it. Decisions are not made based upon what is best for the institution, but rather what is best for the decision maker and their personal career. Chances to save real money and advance the University are often overlooked or stalled because of one persons desire to protect their turf. Much of the campus infrastructure is aged, everything from  network cabling in research buildings to placement of electrical outlets is from the 1960's.  The college has fallen behind the IT curve in general and embraces no modern concepts of having things like a project management office for campus, regular training for employees or feedback sessions where employees can let upper management know what issues are plaguing the college.  The college operates as though it has no money and is some sort of inner city school district but has money for absurd expenses like full color magazine like documents to communicate what the IT strategy is for the year or some obscure HR program that few attend.

review_title: Overall, A Great Place to Work
pros: Can provide a flexible work environment, ability to work with young, talented students and accomplished faculty, large community, well known.
cons: Higher education does not pay well for those that are staff (non-faculty) and staff are considered second class citizens to faculty.

review_title: Case Western is a decent place to work
pros: New president with solid ideas on rebounding from economic downturn.  Some good connections with Cleveland's growing health care community, although UH versus the globally-recognized Cleveland Clinic creates some competitive conflict.
cons: Leadership outside the president and provost is lacking, but that varies by college or staff.

pros: Lots of people doing research in various departments with a fair amount of interdisciplinary research being conducted.  Excellent resources in the library and online.
cons: Although there are so many people doing research, in many department the research truly moves at a snail's pace.  It depends on who your PI is... some are very determined and hardworking but others definitely coast on tenure.

review_title: Less pay, but more educational benefits
pros: Its a great place to learn and work, especially if you are working in research.  You will have access to most of the methods. If your credentials meet the program's criteria and if the coursework is related to your job, you will be allowed to take courses (not in work hours).
cons: Very low pay compared to other institutions.

review_title: I was a graduate student working in optoelectronic research within the physics department.
pros: Experience to do novel science while having some control of the research you are interested in.
cons: Long hours are expected and the pay is low. Familiar situation in other grad. schools

pros: Cleveland is not expensive, so for graduate school or postdoc is probably a good option. CWRU has a strong medical school, so there are researchers that are pretty well known with high ranked research and publications.
cons: The school is mid size, so you will not have many options. CWRU is a private school, so basically you need to pay for everything. Limited benefits, for example no daycare,

job_title: Student Facilities Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: The people who manage you directly are great people who really care about you and your future.  We worked hard, got stuff done, and had a lot of fun and made life long friendships while doing it.
cons: The heads of the department that you don't see every day can be harsh and disconnected from the rest of the workforce.

review_title: Stifling corporate-like environment offering little autonomy
